The chemical potential of bulk Cu is set to zero μbulk = 0; (d) Calculated Bader charge of Cu ions in Cun-doped with respect of Cu bulk species. (For interpretation of the references to colour in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the web version of this article.) Fig. 3 Optimized configurations of CO adsorbed on CuxCe1-xO2 solid solutions. (a) Cu1-dop-Ov; (b) Cu2-dop; (c) Cu3-dop; (d) Cu4-dop; Colour code: red (O in CeO2), magenta (O in CO), brown (Cu) and beige (Ce). (e) Simulated IR spectra of Cuδ+–CO species on the Cu1-dop-Ov, Cu2-dop, Cu3-dop, and Cu4-dop, respectively. (For interpretation of the references to colour in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the web version of this article.) Fig. 4 Reaction mechanism and corresponding potential energy profile. (a) and (b) Schemes of CO oxidation mechanism via O2 association and O2 dissociation pathway for CO oxidation; (c) Potential energy diagrams for CO oxidation via O2 dissociation for Cu3-dop and Cu4-dop; inset exhibit the optimized structure for the intermediates and transition states for Cu3-dop; Colour code: red (O in CeO2), magenta (O in CO), brown (Cu) and beige (Ce). (For interpretation of the references to colour in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the web version of this article.) Fig. 5 (a) The corresponding Arrhenius plots of the turnover frequency (TOF) of CO oxidation over these CuxCe1-xO2 solid solution models and (b) the corresponding conversions versus temperature. Graphical abstract Identifying the local environments of active sites of CuxCe1-xO2 solid solution for low-temperature CO oxidation remains significant challenges. In this study, we coupled density functional theory and microkinetic modeling to thoroughly investigate local structures of CuxCe1-xO2 solid solution catalysts, as well as its catalytic performance for low-temperature CO oxidation. Combined with the infrared spectra simulations, we propose that the substitution of Cu3 or Cu4 clusters for one Ce atom accounts for the experimentally observed vibrational peaks of the adsorbed CO, rather than the Cu single atom or dimer. Cu single-atom and Cun clusters (n = 2–4) doped into CeO2 all exhibit an excellent stability against ripening and a promising catalytic activity for low-temperature CO oxidation. This research for the first time elucidates the nature of CuxCe1-xO2 solid solution catalysts and paves the way for the rational design of Cu/CeO2 catalysts for CO oxidation. Keywords Density functional theory CO oxidation Cu-CeO2 solid solution Dynamic evolution Cluster doping Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Ceria (CeO2) is an important component in environmental catalysis with main applications in the cleanup of exhaust gases, owing to its excellent oxygen storage capacity and the reversible redox characteristics of Ce4+/Ce3+ cations[1–3]. The propensity to stabilize transition metals in high dispersion renders CeO2 an excellent support in heterogeneous catalysis, including the incorporation of metal cations into CeO2 lattice to form solid solutions which is generally deemed to a kind of single-atom catalysts and an analogy of homogeneous catalysts [4,5]. The introduction of transition metal dopants can significantly lower the formation energy of lattice oxygen vacancies, and the metal dopants prefer a square-planar coordination rather than the incipient octahedral coordination of lattice Ce atoms [6,7]. Ascribed to the activated lattice oxygen, TMxCe1-xO2 (TM=Pt, Pd, Ni, Cu, etc.) solid solutions generally exhibit an excellent stability and catalytic activity of low-temperature CO oxidation [2,8–10]. Despite PtxCe1-xO2 and PdxCe1-xO2 solid solutions, CuxCe1-xO2 solid solution catalyst is increasingly used in three-way catalysis because of it is low price and excellent activity for low-temperature CO oxidation [11–13]. Shao-Horn and co-workers demonstrated that Cu3+ and Cu2+ of CuyCe1−yO2−x solid solution serve as active sites for low-temperature CO oxidation[14]. Abdel-Mageed et al. suggested that formation of Cu2+/Cu+ redox shuttles in CuxCe1-xO2 solid solution plays a dual role for CO adsorption and O2 activation [15]. Nonetheless, the efficacy of CuxCe1-xO2 catalysts and their catalytic activities strongly depend on dispersion states of the incorporated Cu atoms within the matrix of the CeO2. Earlier, Li and Shen found that the Ce1-xCuxOy solid solutions and small CuO cluster coexist with increase of Cu loading [16]. Recently, Liu and co-workers observed that surface segregation of Cu atoms can lead to the formation of CuOx and a surface Cu-doped ceria thin-layer for a much-enhanced CO oxidation activity [3]. Yan and co-workers synthesized the sintered copper-ceria catalyst which contains the coordination-unsaturated Cu1O3 sites for the remarkable CO oxidation activity [17]. These experimental investigations demonstrate that determining the location of highly dispersed Cu into surface CeO2 lattice remains a big challenge. It is possible that more Cu atoms substitute for one Ce atom, because ionic radius of both Cu2+ and Cu+ cations is much smaller than that of Ce4+ cation. Thus, it is substantially necessary to make clear the local environments of doped Cu species (single atom or cluster) into CeO2 matrix. In this study, a series of CuxCe1-xO2 solid solution models were constructed by replacing one Ce atom of CeO2(111) surface using single Cu atom, double Cu atoms, Cu3 and Cu4 clusters. Comprehensive density functional theory (DFT) calculations were conducted to investigate the structure evolution of CuxCe1-xO2 solid solution and their characteristically catalytic activity for low-temperature CO oxidation coupled Infrared (IR) spectra simulation and micro-kinetic modelling. We identified the structure of CuxCe1-xO2 solid solution by calculating the CO adsorption strength and IR peak positions of the Cuδ+–CO complex. The results demonstrate that the experimentally observed CO adsorption sites of CuxCe1-xO2 solid solution may involve the Cu3 or Cu4 cluster rather than single and double Cu atoms. All doping models display a promising catalytic activity of low temperature CO oxidation. 2 Results and discussion 2.1 Structure of CuxCe1-xO2 solid solutions Traditionally, substituting Cu single atom for one Ce atom of CeO2 represents the CuxCe1-xO2 solid solution [18,19], and the Cu dopant displays a feature of Cu2+ ion and adopts a square-planar coordination of four lattice oxygen atoms, accompanied with one oxygen vacancy (OV) formation (named as Cu1-dop-Ov) to maintain charge balance [6]. Considering the much smaller ionic radius of Cu2+ and Cu+ than Ce4+ cations (0.73 and 0.46 Å vs. 0.97 Å) and their different oxidation states, we introduce the second, third and fourth Cu atoms on the doping sites to form the correspond solid solution models (Cu2-dop, Cu3-dop and Cu4-dop) as shown in Figs. 1 a-b. The construction rules of solid solution models can be simply described as 1) ionic radius matching and 2) charge conservation as illustrated in Fig. 1 a. These specific local stoichiometries were chosen to systematically study the stability and properties of the resulting solid solutions. Besides, the high energy barriers for Ce migration suggest that Ce4+ vacancies are stable and unoccupied under the studied conditions, thus facilitating the formation of Cun-dop through Cu migration ( Figs. S1-S2 ) [20]. In Cu2-dop, one Cu atom coordinates with four lattice O atoms, and another is three-fold coordination with a binding energy to the first Cu atom of −5.31 eV, much stronger than the cohesive energy of Cu bulk. As such, the binding energy of the third and fourth Cu atom to Cu3-dop and Cu4-dop is −3.69 eV and −3.75 eV, respectively. The exposed Cu atoms in both Cu3-dop and Cu4-dop retain three-fold coordination with lattice O atoms and can serve as the active sites for CO chemisorption. Fig. 1c shows that the chemical potential of the doped Cu atoms ranges between −0.46 eV and −2.49 eV, with Cu1-dop-Vo having the highest value of −2.49 eV, indicating it is the most stable configuration. This is followed by Cu2-dop (−2.08 eV), Cu4-dop (−0.52 eV) and Cu3-dop (−0.46 eV). The stability hierarchy demonstrates that single Cu atoms in vacancy sites (Cu1-dop-Vo) are more stable than configurations with multiple Cu atoms. Additionally, all the candidates exhibit significantly lower values than those of Cu nanoparticles (NPs). These results indicate that the doped Cu atoms are sufficiently stable to resist spillover and prevent agglomeration into Cu NPs on the CeO2 surface, suggesting that the doping site could serve as a potential nucleation center. Moreover, extended calculations reveal that the binding energies of the fifth, sixth, and seventh Cu atoms in Cu atom to Cu5-dop (−3.13 eV), Cu6-dop (−3.25 eV), and Cu7-dop (−3.05 eV) clusters (Fig.S3) are lower than the cohesive energy of bulk Cu. Resultingly, the clustering of Cu atoms on doping sites to large NPs may take place once the Cu loading keeps increasing [3,16]. To further verify the thermodynamic stability of the above-mentioned systems, we performed ab initio molecular dynamics (AIMD) simulations at 300 K. The simulations were conducted in the NVT ensemble with a time step of 1 fs over 10 ps by using Nose-Hoover thermostats to maintain the system temperature. Fig. S4 shows the energy variation and the structure after the 10 ps AIMD simulation. The overall energy remained stable throughout the simulation, indicating that the structures are thermodynamically stable at 300 K. Moreover, the Cu–O bond length remains stable without significant fluctuations or changes as shown in Fig. S5, indicating that the above systems are thermodynamically stable at 300 K during the simulation time. We further conducted the Bader analysis as shown in Fig. 1d , and herein, we take the Bader charges of CuO, Cu2O and Cu bulk as the reference. The results show that oxidation state of the first doped Cu atom in all four solid solution models is close to Cu2+ cation, as well as the second doped Cu atom in Cu2-dop model. While in both Cu3-dop and Cu4-dop models, the second, third and fourth Cu atoms retain an oxidation state of Cu+ cation. Besides, in Cu4-dop model, one Ce3+ cation (magnetic moment μB=0.976) is produced owing to the electron transfer from Cu to Ce atom, in agreement with charge conservation (2Ce4+ → Ce3+ + Cu2+ + 3Cu+). To examine the oxidation states of the doped Cun clusters under work conditions of catalyst synthesis and CO oxidation, we probed the adsorption of O atoms on the Cun-dop (n = 2–4) structures (Fig. S6) and examine the thermodynamic stability of the described structures with respect to temperature and O2 partial pressure by using an ab initio thermodynamic analysis. As shown in Fig. 2 , the doped Cu2, Cu3 and Cu4 clusters do not prefer to adsorb O atoms under the classical synthesis conditions (e.g. 500 ℃ and 1 atm) of CuxCe1-xO2 solid solutions and remain the states without O adsorption under reaction conditions (e.g. 200 ℃ and 10-5 atm) of low-temperature CO oxidation. These findings suggest that the candidate configurations exhibit considerable stability under oxygen atmosphere. We also simulated the scanning tunnelling microscopy (STM) images as shown in Fig. S7. The simulated STM images demonstrate that the doped Cu atom in the Cu1-dop-Ov model cannot show a bright spot because it lies on subsurface and is 0.66 and 1.32 Å lower than surface Ce and O atoms, respectively. While the exposed Cu atoms of Cu2-dop, Cu3-dop and Cu4-dop can account for the bright spots in the experimentally observed STM images of CuxCe1-xO2 solid solutions [21,22], because they reside at the similar elevation to surface O atoms. The results demonstrate that the doped Cun clusters can agree better with experimental characterization than the doped Cu single atoms. 2.2 CO adsorption and simulated IR spectra To further make clear the local environments of CuxCe1-xO2 solid solution, we thoroughly investigate the CO adsorption behaviours on these four models. As depicted in Fig. 3 , Cu1-dop-Ov model displays a weak CO adsorption of −0.57 eV, in accordance with our previous findings [6]. Fig. 3e shows the correspondingly predicted IR peak position of adsorbed CO molecule is at 2013 cm−1, far away from the experimental observation between 2090 and 2112 cm−1 listed in Table 1 . Besides, the experimental IR characterization is generally implemented at a temperature above 100 ℃, indicating that the CO binding strength should be stronger than 0.8 eV taking entropy of gaseous CO into account. For example, Shao-Horn and co-workers found that the IR band at 2110 cm−1 of CO on CuxCe1-xO2 solid solution gradually disappears till 160 ℃ (entropy of circa 0.9 eV) [23]. While the linear CO adsorption on the coordination-unsaturated Cu atoms of Cu2-dop, Cu3-dop and Cu4-dop gets much stronger, and the adsorption energy is −1.03, −1.29 and −1.05 eV, respectively. The strong chemisorption can counteract the entropy contribution of gaseous CO and hold experimental IR observation of the formed Cu2+–CO or Cu+–CO species. The Cu2+–CO species of Cu2-dop exhibits a vibrational frequency of 2145 cm−1, much higher than the experimental values. While the predicted vibrational frequency of Cu+–CO species on Cu3-dop and Cu4-dop are 2102 cm−1 and 2090 cm−1, respectively, in line with the experimental observations listed in Table 1. Besides, the CO adsorbed on the bare Cu(111), Cu2O(111) and CuO(111) surface and the simulated IR spectra of Cuδ+–CO species were also calculated and shown in Fig. S8 and Table S1. Additionally, it has been reported that Cu+–CO interactions exhibit greater thermal stability compared to Cu2+–CO interactions. Jia and co-workers found that the Cu2+ cations in CuxCe1-xO2 solid solution may not easily adsorb CO and the thermal stability of Cu2+–CO was much lower than that of Cu+–CO under DRIFTS conditions [11]. These Cu+–CO interactions are thus deemed more favourable active species for subsequent CO oxidation [33,34]. Thus, we deduce that the experimentally observed Cu+–CO species in CuxCe1-xO2 solid solution is more likely produced on the active sites that consist of three or four Cu atoms rather than single or double Cu atoms. We mainly consider CO oxidation via the Mars-van Krevelen mechanism, which can be divided into two pathways depending on the difficulty of O2 dissociation on oxygen vacancies: O2 association pathway for Cu1-dop-VO and Cu2-dop models and O2 dissociation pathway for Cu3-dop and Cu4-dop models (Fig. 4 a and b). The initiation of the CO oxidation cycle involves the adsorption of CO onto the catalyst surface (state ii), then the adsorbed CO interacts with a surface lattice O atom overcoming modest barrier energies of 0.11, 0.09, 0.24 and 0.38 eV for Cu1-dop-VO and Cun-dop (n = 2–4), respectively, shown in Fig. 3c and Fig. S9. This CO2 formation is an exothermic process by 2.12, 1.24, 0.21 and 0.42 eV, respectively. The CO2 desorption costs energy of 0.61, 0.36, 0.94 and 1.46 eV, respectively, and one VO is generated for subsequent O2 capture and activation. On Cu3-dop and Cu4-dop models, the O2 dissociation is facile overcoming a low energy barrier of 0.13 and 0.15 eV, respectively. While, on Cu1-dop-VO and Cu2-dop models, the O2 dissociation gets more difficult and the required energy barrier is 1.03 and 0.97 eV, respectively. Without O2 dissociation, the energy barriers of next CO oxidation respectively occurring on Cu3-dop and Cu4-dop models are as high as 0.91 and 0.92 eV (Fig. S10), while those are 0.17 and 0.21 eV on Cu1-dop-VO and Cu2-dop models, respectively. Therefore, we consider CO oxidation via the O2-asscociation mechanism on Cu1-dop-VO and Cu2-dop models and O2-dissociation mechanism on Cu3-dop and Cu4-dop models, respectively. O2 dissociation refills VO and produces one excess O atom on Cu3-dop and Cu4-dop models, and then the adsorption energy of second CO is −0.58 and −0.86 eV, respectively. The following CO2 formation by combining the co-adsorbed CO and O atom requires an energy barrier of 0.35 and 0.31 eV, respectively. And then the catalytic cycle of CO oxidation is closed after facile CO2 desorption. The optimized configurations of Cu2-dop and Cu4-dop in CO oxidation cycle were shown in Figs.S11-12. To further identify the catalytic activity of CO oxidation, micro-kinetic simulations were performed. Fig. 5 a shows the turnover frequency (TOF) at different temperatures, and the Cu1-dop-VO and Cu2-dop models both display higher catalytic activity than Cu3-dop and Cu4-dop models below 573 K. The exceptional activity of Cu1-dop-VO and Cu2-dop may stem from the efficient activation of lattice O adjacent to Cu dopants, and the corresponding VO formation energy is merely 1.21 and 1.56 eV, respectively, much lower than that of pure CeO2(111) surface (2.39 eV). While doping of Cu3 and Cu4 clusters inactivate the adjoining lattice O atoms due to the strong metal-support interaction, and VO formation energy is 2.72 and 3.25 eV, respectively. The moderate CO binding strength still hold the promising catalytic activity for low-temperature CO oxidation due to their low overall energy barriers. Correspondingly, the Cu1-dop-VO and Cu2-dop models show a 100 % conversion under a low temperature as shown in Fig. 5b. The Cu3-dop and Cu4-dop models, displays higher predicted temperatures for 100 % conversion at 320 and 440 K, respectively, agreeing well with the experimental observation [17,23,34]. Therefore, we suggest that Cu3-dop and Cu4-dop models can better describe the CuxCe1-xO2 solid solution catalysts and the doping sites containing single or double Cu atoms may also coexist, although Cu1-dop-VO and Cu2-dop models cannot provide the experimentally observed IR bands of CO molecules. 3 Conclusions In this work, systematic investigations were conducted to explore the nature of CuxCe1-xO2 solid solution catalysts and their performance in low-temperature CO oxidation by means of DFT calculations and MKM analysis. The theoretical prediction of IR peak positions for Cun-carbonyl complexes and STM simulations of candidate models of CuxCe1-xO2 solid solution corroborate that the doping sites involve Cu3 or Cu4 clusters instead of the single or double Cu atoms. The doped single Cu atom renders a weak CO adsorption and IR band at 2013 cm−1, far away from the experimental observation circa 2090–2110 cm−1. These doped Cu atoms or clusters are all stable enough against sintering. The activity investigation shows that the doping sites involving Cu3 or Cu4 clusters display a promising catalytic activity of low-temperature CO oxidation, while those containing single or double Cu atoms exhibit better. We for the first time clarify the nature of local chemical environments of CuxCe1-xO2 solid solution catalysts and identify the corresponding catalytic activity of low-temperature CO oxidation. The study also provides new insights into the solid solution catalysts with sufficient catalytic activity and stability. coredata.dc:description: Identifying the local environments of active sites of CuxCe1-xO2 solid solution for low-temperature CO oxidation remains significant challenges. In this study, we coupled density functional theory and microkinetic modeling to thoroughly investigate local structures of CuxCe1-xO2 solid solution catalysts, as well as its catalytic performance for low-temperature CO oxidation. Combined with the infrared spectra simulations, we propose that the substitution of Cu3 or Cu4 clusters for one Ce atom accounts for the experimentally observed vibrational peaks of the adsorbed CO, rather than the Cu single atom or dimer. Cu single-atom and Cun clusters (n = 2–4) doped into CeO2 all exhibit an excellent stability against ripening and a promising catalytic activity for low-temperature CO oxidation. This research for the first time elucidates the nature of CuxCe1-xO2 solid solution catalysts and paves the way for the rational design of Cu/CeO2 catalysts for CO oxidation.

coredata.dc:title: Nature of CuxCe1-xO2 solid solution catalysts
